					I‚Äôve been working on A/V equipment for work lately. Mostly due to lots of meetings occuring. Of course, when people want a system to perform flawlessly, it rarely does so. While I have no ‚Äúreal‚Äù A/V experience, I can turn things on and off, or plug and unplug things. That makes me well suited for the IT industry.
					This leads me to yesterday. A Very Important Meeting is going on and one of the screens connected has a weird flickering issue. Attempts to restart the display and the meeting fail to mete out results. So, I work my way down the chain. Behind this display is the HDMI connection, attached to this is an odd little ‚Äúinterposer‚Äù. Not knowing what this does, I removed it and plugged the cable directly into the display, which immediately clears up the issue. Problem solved. On to the next thing.
					
						
							
								
									
										
											
											
											
										
										The unmarked EDID Emulator in question
									
								
							
							
								
									
										
											
											
											
										
										The unmarked EDID Emulator in question
									
								
							
							
								
									
										
											
											
											
										
										The unmarked EDID Emulator in question
									
								
							
						
					
					But‚Ä¶ what is this little thing? It has no obvious markings other than a generic serial number. My initial guess is that it‚Äôs some sort of signal filter like you would find in the old analog days of VGA, where a ferrite ballast would be attached to the cable to help filter out noise on the line. HDMI is digital though. If the signal isn‚Äôt a 1 or a 0, then it‚Äôs not anything. So, that‚Äôs out.
					One of my colleagues, who does do A/V, and specifically these room setups discovers that they‚Äôre something called HDMI EDID emulators. What are they? Well‚Ä¶
					It turns out that some companies cut corners while implementing standard interfaces. While their gear might still work, it might also be implementing only part of the full requirements for the specification. They get away with it because:
					
						
							It‚Äôs cheap, so people don‚Äôt care
						
						
							It ‚Äúworks‚Äù, so people don‚Äôt care
						
					
					Standards are that way for a reason, however, I know that not everyone behaves according to that. That makes me sad. It opens up new, werid markets for ‚Äúfixing‚Äù these sorts of oddball issues. Sad, but even professional standards are sinking.

How I Build This Site
						üîó
					
					10:38:47 on 2023-01-11
				
				
					When I set up this site, I was iterating on a site
					infrastructure that I had done previously. A very simple
					setup of using S3's 'static site' function to provide a
					front-end to a bucket. I would then use DNS to point to the
					endpoint S3 static hostname. This worked well, for a time.
					However, this was not as fast as it could be. Mainly,
					because every request would hit the East Coast bucket
					endpoint every time. There were no closer endpoints unless
					you manually set up another bucket with static site hosting
					in a different region. Boo üëé.
					CloudFront
					Amazon, of course, has a solution for this. Allow their
					caching front end CloudFront to handle the requests. This
					will put your content into geographically closer endpoints
					on their network. If the content isn't already there, it‚Äôll
					be fetched from the source bucket automatically. Not only
					does this make connectivity faster for your users, but
					allows you to have only one end point where your source
					files are. Each distribution point getting updated as
					needed.
					Building
					Making this all work with minimal hassle took some time
					to figure out how things work in
						AWS. It's not
						fully
						automated, either. It‚Äôs comfortably, for me, automated
						so that the important parts that take the most time to
						do are done easily. It‚Äôs also flexible enough that you
						could substitute in a different system that you'd prefer
						to use (like Azure or Netlify or whatever).
					0. Content
					I presume that you have some content you‚Äôd like to
					publish. Be it a Single Page App, or a blog generated with
					one of those Static Site Generators. It could even be a
					single page blog like mine. It doesn't really matter. You
					have a folder full of stuff you‚Äôd like to host.
					I save mine in GitHub, so this prerequisite is to have
					Git available. Again, your choice. You can have content from
					where ever, even on something like DropBox. Whatever works
					for you
					1. Location
					I set up my site on AWS, so I‚Äôll be talking about that.
					My system involves a single bucket where CloudFront is going
					to be getting its data from. I don't do anything special to
					this bucket. Actually, that's not entirely true.
					Later, I set up a user with permissions to access this
					bucket, but I've not set the public access or static site
					permissions on the bucket. Mostly, I've left it as-is. You
					can feel free to upload the content at this point.
					2. Caching
					CloudFront is next. Setting up a
						distribution is fairly straight-forward. You‚Äôll
						want to choose the endpoints that matter to you. I‚Äôve
						chosen North America and Europe. While I‚Äôm sure there
						are folks who would like to read my blog from elsewhere
						in the world. I‚Äôm not sure if it matters much. You can
						leave this option on "Use all edge locations". You will
						be paying slightly more per request, but it likely
						doesn‚Äôt even matter unless you‚Äôre dealing with millions
						or billions of requests.
					You can also set up the names you want the site to
					respond to. Make sure that you have any subdomains that you
					want to respond, as well. Things like www. is a
					subdomain that people forget. You can add it later, but it
					might mess up your certificate generation in the next
					part.
					If you want an SSL-secured site, then you can have Amazon
					generate you a certificate automatically. I did, it‚Äôs cheap
					and simple and since I also use Route 53, it‚Äôs automatically
					setup and verified for me. If you have your own certificate,
					you can upload it from here, too.
					Another bit of automation is that you can set up an OAI
						for exclusive access from CloudFront to the source
						bucket. While this requires a bit of juggling with the
						console (copy the rules from the distribution into the
						S3 bucket policies), it‚Äôs worth it. This means that you
						don‚Äôt have to expose the bucket to the world. Only
						CloudFront.
					On Redirection
					As an aside, there are methods to allow you to create URL
					redirects from within CloudFront. It‚Äôs not the easiest thing
					to implement, but it does work. Basically, you need to set
					up a CloudFront function that will be used to
					inspect the requests as they come in and redirect as needed.
					Here‚Äôs a sample of mine:
					function handler(event) {
    const request = event.request;

    switch (request.uri)
    {
        case request.uri.startsWith('/wishlist'):
            // redirect to wishlist
            return {
                statusCode: 308,
                statusDescription: 'Permanent Redirect',
                headers: {
                    "location": {
                        "value": "https://mywishlist.online/w/75dd8k/nathans-wishlist"
                    }
                }
            };
    }

    // Last resort, just return the URL
    return request;
}
					This code looks at the request and makes a decision based
					on if the URL request starts with
						/wishlist. If it does, then redirect it to
						a new URL of my choice. You can get pretty crazy here,
						but keep in mind that they will charge you extra
						depending on how much time this code takes to
						execute.
					3. Glue
					Finally, I use a
						Makefile to actually upload the files to
						AWS, and then
						invalidate the current CloudFront cache. This
						ensures that CloudFront endpoints have the latest
						content available to it. Generally, this looks like two
						commands to the awscli tool:
aws s3 sync . s3://your-bucket-name --quiet --exclude ".git**" --exclude ...
aws cloudfront create-invalidation --distribution-id YOURCLOUDFRONTID --paths=/\*
					Fin
					There's not a lot going on with the mechanics of the
					site. Mostly it's just the setup of the infrastructure in
					AWS, first, then pushing the content up and making sure that
					things are fresh for users.
					You can
					see the code I use on GitHub.

X Window Basics

					Back in the day (like today) people use the relatively
					   ancient X Windows system on Linux systems to display windows
					   and other graphical treats. This system has evolved and
					   changed over its long history, as any piece of software
					   might. The flexibility of the X Window system shows that
					   even though it is old, it's still able to be quite modern.

					A series of articles (and live demos) written by Jasper St.
					      Pierre, goes into a high-level overview of how this amazing
					   system works, and continues to work, in the modern era.
					   While Wayland may be all the rage, some of us are still
					   living with this amazing historical piece of engineering.

More Emacs Archaeology: Input Methods
						üîó
					
					18:52:52 on 2022-12-14
				
				
					Input methods, or, the way you put in non-ASCII
					characters is likely not archaeology for
					much of the world, but it's something I don't know
					much about. Plus, I learned a couple of neat
					tricks. So "archaeology" it is.
					Emacs has a rather complete set of input
					methods. Given that it was born and refined in the
					terminal days, where common non-ASCII input
					systems were probably not the norm, it handles
					lots of different languages and keyboard layouts.
					However, there appear to be some useful layouts
					that are more than mere "input methods":
					One such method is the sgml input
					method (accessed by C-\). This converts
					any proper HTML encoding sequence after
					an & character into the display
					equivalent. So characters
					like ‚Ä¶ are turned into
					ellipses, or ‚Ñ¢ is turned into
					the Trademark logo. Pretty neat! You can do a
					similar thing for LaTeX documents with
					the TeX input method.
					So, you might have been thinking: "Doesn't this
					kind of sit inside of the prettify-symbol
					wheelhouse of replacing sequences of characters
					with a pretty glyph?" Or perhaps you were
					thinking: "Why not just setup some easy
					abbreviations with abbrev?" For some of the more
					astute among my Emacs readers might also say:
					"Hey! You can just press C-x 8 and
					input pretty much any unicode symbol!
					What's the point of this?".
					You, of course, would be correct. There are
					lots of ways of handling this. Abbrevs and
					prettify symbol both do what you ask, one altering
					the text and one not. And yes, you are right when
					you say you could use the unicode insertion macro.
					All true. However, as in input method, this
					feature is easily toggled and in doing so
					allows you to continue writing, without having to
					break your stride too much. That said, I don't
					think I'll have much of a place to use it in the
					future. I'm not writing documents anymore, and my
					coding days are behind me. Maybe, one day, I'll
					need it for something. On that day, I'll be glad
					I'm using Emacs.

## File: ~/.inputrc

# Show color in completions

Package Install Without Use-Package
						üîó
					
					15:13:15 on 2022-11-20
				
				
					So, one of the things I had to sort out when
						slimming down on the amount of external packages
						that I use is to get things installed
						without use-package. Typically, I
						used a form that looked a lot like this:
					
						
(unless (package-installed-p 'package)
	(package-refresh-contents)
	(package-install 'package))
						
					
					For a small amount of packages, this was fine,
						even if it was inefficient by refreshing the
						package contents for each instance of that. It was
						barely a problem with 1 or 2 packages.
					Of course, there is a much more
						efficient manner, already built into Emacs, and
						much easier to implement:
					
						
(setq package-selected-packages '(ef-themes emms))
(package-install-selected-packages)
						
					
					Yeah. So, just make a list of package names you
						want to install and uh, tell it to do that. No
						multiple refreshes, just here's what I want, go do
						that. Magic.

						everyone behaves this way, and no one is an expert. However,
						that is clearly not the case. People may not know every
						aspect of a thing they have expertise in. However, for all
						intents and purposes, they're an 'expert'. I just wish I
